reviewText:
Tactical Intervention is a multiplayer FPS developed by Minh Gooseman" Le who earlier co-developed counter-strike. This does seem like a good way to make a comeback but Tactical Intervention suffers some major drawbacks.

The game itself seems just like a standard multiplayer FPS. You get a gun wich you then run around and shoot people in the head with and eventually get shot in the head yourself. Seems fairly simple right? But the game got these nice little small details wich varies from using a fire extinguisher to put up a smoke wall to being able to roll away from explosions and thereby prevent taking damage. This is according to myself the only positive point of the entire game.

The gameplay is also one of the worst of modern day FPS games. It's not that it's bad but it's just nothing special.
And don't get me started on the animations. Everyone looks like crabs when they walk around!
And with just around 500 ppl in game at the time this is written? The game has been out for less than a year and the community is alredy dying out.

As a F2P title the game functions as a good example of a Pay 2 Win game (P2W). This means that the people who pay for stuff in the game (be it a more powerful weapon or even dogs) can totally dominate the people who don't. So someone who is far more skilled may get totally rolled over by someone far less skilled just because the far lessed skilled guy has put more money on the table.

PROS
+ Good ideas that later FPS games may improve
+ Better than COD
+ So bad it's funny if you're in the right mood

CONS
- P2W
- Laughable animations
- The community is barely alive

OVERALL SCORE 32/100"

I don't know what to write, so here's the recipe for chocolate chip cookies:

Ingredients
1/2 cup (1 stick) unsalted butter
3/4 cup packed dark brown sugar
3/4 cup sugar
2 large eggs
1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract
1 (12-ounce) bag semisweet chocolate chips, or chunks
2 1/4 cups all-purpose flour
3/4 teaspoon baking soda
1 teaspoon fine salt

Directions
Evenly position 2 racks in the middle of the oven and preheat to 375 degrees F. (on convection setting if you have it.) Line 2 baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone sheets. (If you only have 1 baking sheet, let it cool completely between batches.)

Put the butter in a microwave safe bowl, cover and microwave on medium power until melted. (Alternatively melt in a small saucepan.) Cool slightly. Whisk the sugars, eggs, butter and vanilla in a large bowl until smooth.

Whisk the flour, baking soda and salt in another bowl. Stir the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients with a wooden spoon; take care not to over mix. Stir in the chocolate chips or chunks.

Scoop heaping tablespoons of the dough onto the prepared pans. Wet hands slightly and roll the dough into balls. Space the cookies about 2-inches apart on the pans. Bake, until golden, but still soft in the center, 12 to 16 minutes, depending on how chewy or crunchy you like your cookies. Transfer hot cookies with a spatula to a rack to cool. Serve.

Store cookies in a tightly sealed container for up to 5 days.

For a  Rocky Road  Bar
Lightly butter a 9 by 13-inch baking pan. Make the batter as per cookie recipe and fold in 1 cup chopped walnuts along with the chocolate chips. Spread batter in prepared pan. Bake until the edges are light brown and the batter sets, about 45 minutes. Cool slightly and cover surface with 4 cups marshmallows and 1 cup chocolate chips. Broil at least 8 inches from the heat until marshmallows turn golden brown, about 2 minutes. (Keep an eye on the marshmallows, and turn the pan frequently--they go from golden to char in a wink.) Cool, cut and serve.

Never played this game but Steam said that I actually did so instead of judging the game here's a cool way to make skinny guacamoles with homemade baked tortilla chips :

Skinny Guacamole:

2 medium green sweet peppers
2 medium fresh poblano chile peppers
1 bulb garlic
1/2 teaspoon olive oil
2 roma tomatoes, seeded and chopped
1 serrano pepper, minced
2 medium ripe avocados, halved, seeded, peeled, and diced
1 teaspoon lime zest
2 tablespoons lime juice
1/2 teaspoon salt

Baked Tortilla Chips:

Corn tortillas
Olive oil spray
Salt

For the guacamole:

Preheat oven to 425° F. Line a 15 x 10 x 1-inch baking pan with foil; set aside. Quarter, stem, and seed the peppers. Place pepper quarters, cut sides down, in the prepared pan. Cut off the top half inch of the garlic bulb to expose ends of individual cloves. Leaving garlic bulb whole, remove any loose, papery outer layers. Place bulb, cut end up, on a double thickness of foil. Drizzle with the oil. Bring foil up around bulb and fold edges together to loosely enclose. Place foil packet on the pan with the peppers.
Roast peppers and garlic for 20 to 30 minutes or until pepper skins are charred and garlic cloves feel soft. Allow to cool about 15 minutes. When garlic head is cool enough to handle, squeeze garlic paste out of the individual cloves.
In a food processor combine roasted pepper quarters and the garlic paste. Cover and pulse until combined, but still slightly chunky.
In a large bowl, combine tomatoes and serrano pepper. Add roasted pepper and garlic combination and stir to combine. Add diced avocado, lime zest, lime juice, and salt. Gently toss to combine.
Serve immediately or cover the surface with plastic wrap and chill for up to 1 hour.
For the chips:

Cut corn tortillas into wedges and place on a foil-lined baking sheet. Spray lightly with olive oil spray and season with salt, to taste.
Bake in a 350° F oven for 8-10 minutes or until lightly golden brown.

reviewText:
Tactical Intervention is...interesting. While not being tactical in any way, it does live up to its name; being an intervention. While many people are on a high from Counter Strike, and CS:GO, T.I. seems like a very possible alternative to dive into. However, even with its decent map design and solid mission modes; T.I. fails in many regards. Keep in mind, this is a free game.

Game Play synopsis -

- pay to win does not always win. I found that after a couple hours playing, years back, i could stand my own with an M4 and buying light armor with the in-game points. *Save your GP*

- Shotguns = the noob cannon. I find the best way to deal with these players, is to just stay away. There is always some off chance that a stray bullet with decide to fly across the map and nail you with a headshot. However, the gore and carnage that is left in their path is quite enjoyable to watch.

- invest in a decent pair of boots. Speed is key, and with no universal speed, the ones who can run are the ones who can survive.

- camping is possible but hard to pull off. The feature to spot where your attacker killed you from is a great advantage. *it takes certain skill to defend a corner*

- Spawn time is 10 seconds. Longer than most games, such as C.S. and the instant respawn in a deathmatch.

- The damage stats are garbage. You’ll see damage carry over from previous kills. Upwards of 200, 300, etc. In many cases, 150 damage could be beaten by 140. The number of shots again follows this logic…..oh wait, there is no logic because it makes NO SENSE!

- This game is all about how well you can tolerate those annoying players who live in the middle of nowhere with a ping of +600 and can kill you instantly because they are clipping harder than the Microsoft Word Helper in a paperclip factory.

- You’ll be bombarded by rage quitters, “you’re a 10 yr old boy!” comments, loud music being blasted over the voice chat, and also, the always appreciated, “?how do to change class” stupid questions.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------

General Review:
- Good game
- Its FREE
- Minimal disk space required
- Minimal hardware specs to run at a decent frame rate.
- Not for those who easily rage
- Slightly cartoonish graphics

------------------------------------------------------------------------------

6/10

Quality:

Overall:
6.6/10

reviewText:
I recommend this game to everyone, those who likes FPS games, and those...who don't. It's really fun if you want it to be. Can be a casual shooter game or a competitive one depending on how you wanna play it and who you play it with. Some may say it's not fun because it gets too hard for them, or just that they play with guys who are new to it or with those who just wants to fool around. Don't just assume it is not a fun game just after a few hours of playing it. It can take time for you to get used to.

And even though T.I. is made by the same guys who made C.S., don't compare the two games. Just take it as a whole different game, or at least that's what I suggest.

I like this game a lot. It allows you to get guns permanently, there are achievements that may take you a long time to get, a number of maps and modes to play (after the latest update), driving maps which quite a number of FPSs do not have, and also several skins you can purchase to have a different and a more badass look for your own character. To be honest, I got hooked on this game for months and I still like this game a lot more than other FPSs I have played before. T.I. is also not so much of a 'pay to win' game compared to some of those I have played. Yes it is true you can purchase stronger guns when you are only a level 1 with real cash, but even so, everything can be bought with in game money other than skins. So I personally wouldn't call that pay to win, since you are just buying things to have it faster. It's not like you bought a gun that's only purchaseable with real cash. But well, I respect the opinions of others if they do disagree with me.

But of course, there is also the downside of this game.

1. Little laggy.

There are quite a number of players in this game that face lag. Even though there are players from all over the world, it is still kinda bad. But even so, if you are able to deal with a little lag, it shouldn't affect you that bad. And for those of who you gets really bad lag, like maybe around 20 FPS or lower, if you are using a laptop, try keeping it charged. That's what I do and the lag is gone. May only be for me. I don't know..
Ohh. And if you are playing with lag, I suggest you to not play at driving maps that often. Can be chaotic..

2. T.I. community

Well, just like in most games, there will be people you will meet who are complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s. There will be ragers, whiners,  trolls, etc. Just ignore them if you can't take this kinda crap. And if they annoy you over the microphone, just mute them in-game. Good thing they have that option.. If you are able to deal with them, good for you. If you can't, well....try harder..

3. Hitmarks

After the latest update in July 2014, the hit registers have been screwed up. It's harder to land hits on target now that the hitmarks aren't as accurate compared to before. Not sure if this applies to all guns, but I notice this problem mainly for the assault rifles. Would appreciate it if this issue gets fixed quick, like say..to how it was before the update on April 2014? Then, the hitmarks were dead on.

4. Game development

Sadly, there are only 4-5 developers working on this game at the moment. So, updates can take awhile. But when updates do come, it may not necessarily make the game a 100% better. reviewText:
It's about as far as you can get from Counter-Strike's tense and tactical stand-offs (though maybe that's because of the lack of a 5v5 ranked adversarial mode), but Tactical Intervention still manages to offer satisfying and surprisingly fun action, with a unique blend of old-school mechanics and (for lack of better terminology) New Age multiplayer FPS sensibilities, offering the best of both worlds while steering relatively clear of the excesses of other games on the market...

... except for its in-game economy, which borders on pay-to-win, and doesn't even seem to be doing the developers any favors, monetarily speaking. The starting weapons are decent, make no mistake, but all other weapons which can only be obtained through the in-game store are notoriously overpowered, and other cosmetic gear items provide similarly unbalanced boosts for a variety of stats (truth be told, they don't really seem to do anything either, which is even worse). You're expected to grind matches to obtain points in order to purchase items on a temporary ownership basis, as permanent gear can cost so many points that you'll likely be tempted to pay up with real money (which is probably the intention here).

Still, Tactical Intervention is a game worth trying out, and it does have some value worth offering if you can stick with it. It also has attack dogs, and that makes it worth at least the hard-drive space, in my book.

Command attack dogs, deploy breaching charges, perform drive-bys and control hostage situations!

From the brilliant mind of Minh “Gooseman” Le, the co-creator of the seminal team-based FPS Counter-Strike, comes its spiritual successor, Tactical Intervention. Take your role as either terrorist or counter-terrorist and confront opponents in fierce and frantic combat over a variety of high energy maps wielding authentic real world weapons, from the classic P90 to the terrorist favourite, the AK47.

Featuring unique games modes and mechanics not seen in other shooters, Tactical Intervention allows you to experience first person combat from an entirely new perspective. Hijack a car to take part in an intense highway chase; unload your high-powered Gabard shotgun at the VIP while leaning out the window, as your opponents scramble to protect him. Take out the covering helicopter with a well-placed shot from an RPG while you handbrake turn to broadside your target.

Experience the thrill of rappelling down a building, kicking in the plexiglass, hurling a flash bang, grabbing a hostage as a human shield, and dealing some rapid fire death with your Uzi. Use riot shields to defend yourself against enemy forces and then command your vicious German Shepard attack dog to savage terrorists out of line of sight. Dive to cover and lay down suppressing fire with your Aug assault rifle so your teammates can liberate the terrified hostages.

Combining the strategic elements of modern team-based shooters with the pure thrill of the original Counter Strike series, Tactical Intervention brings a whole new level of gaming to the battlefield and lets players feel the true intensity of battle. With a huge variety of weapons, special equips, authentic combat uniforms and paths to victory, Tactical Intervention truly is the next evolution in team-based combat. So grab your P90, slap on a red-dot, twist in a silencer and dive into TI!

reviewText:
Tactical Intervention is a quite intricate take of things on Counter Strike. Created by a co-creator of CS, I was quite pleased to see the changes they had made to it. With some smarts, and patience, one COULD get really good at it, I thought. To an extent, that may have been true. But I can't help but think the devs were a little too greedy with this game, and a bit unfair in other aspects, as well....
First off, the game is a nice take of CS, with great features like rappelling, player VIP escort, drivable cars, breaching charges too! It all seems great, at first. You'll soon find out that rappelling is worse than useless, noob VIPs get themselves killed, thus ending the round, the cars mechanics are absolutely HORRIBLE, and the breaching charges are overpriced. Oh, did I mention that? EVERY perk, attachment, accessory, pretty much anything besides the actual weapons need actual $$$ to use, and most for only a month, as there is no perma unlock for them. I know, crazy, right? But hear me out.
The guns themselves are decent, save for one. They can be permanently unlocked, but it is a pain in the @$$ to do when you only have the default guns. What's wrong with the default guns, you ask? They are significantly lower dmg, accuracy, and mag size. Useless. Good thing is, you can rent guns to get ingame money to payoff your rent and even profit, with the right application of use.
This needs a seperate paragraph of its own. The Super V. Basically the Vector, it outclasses the M4, AK, G36, every other SMG and assault rifle, destroys shotguns and pistols, and snipers aren't even a challange, unless they have 50 meters on you. Even then, its anyone's guess. Accuracy, damage, RPM, this gun has it all. You can use it in a car, on land, in hell, anywhere. It will ruin the poor fool in front. Devs need to fix this, FAST, or this game could quickly degnerate into people relying on other people's sense of goodwill and benevolence.
Honestly though, my take of this game is that it is very good. It has a small community really, so once you meet the right people, (the decent ones with hearts), you will be able to actually play with them, use some strategy, maybe. Strategy in this game, with a closely knit, communicative, strong team will beat almost any opposition out there. Maybe a rehaul in graphics, but that's a minor thing, definitely a change in the whole $$$ grabbing thing, though. Change the way you get the accessories, attachments, aesthetical changes, etc, and maybe TI will get a larger following. That, and a basic autobalance so that it isn't all lvl 40-50s on one team, and like 5 lvl 1-4's on the other. I still reccommend this game, because hey, if you don't give up on it, and you persist, it will quickly grow on you after a while. Then fall off. But let that happen later.

reviewText:
UPDATE 1


Many people compare TI to CS, which is understandable, because of the Gooseman’s legacy and that the TI “feels/looks” the closes to CS, but TI is not CS and that is the reason why people like me and all the rest of the dedicated TI players like the game. If I have to describe/compare with a single sentence both of the game I would say “If CS is like a professional boxing with strict rules and limitations, then TI is like MMA (Mixed Martial Arts).” CS is stripped from any kind of “tunings” except the bullet vest/helmet and the defuse kit, which is good for competitive/sport matches (you know what to expect). But in the other hand TI is more arcade, you can tune/create your own “class and style” of game play similar to Team Fortress 2, but without the limitations of predefined classes. You still need some skills to shoot precisely (deal with recoil), use tactics (communicate), use grenades, which I love how they behaves, not like in CS (in CS there are just two useful grenades, flash bang and smoke all the rest are joke), when you throw frag grenade, tear gas, smoke, flash bang you know what to expect and the other side have to get the hell out from there, if they want to survive and even so they still can be blinded for a while after or knocked down from the blast or have a blurred vision, smoke is passive grenade and the incendiary is more or less like the smoke to create a barrier, but not to kill. You can rush/run for your life or to attack, you can peak, you can roll, there is bullet penetration (although not always predictable and sticking guns from the glass walls make greater damage than no sticking, but hey no one is perfect ;)). There is a map and if you make noise (shooting, running or even moving will give your position away) good for ambushing campers. And if you get tired from all that bomb, rescue, escort game play, then you have cars :). There are plenty of weapons, gears and perks to choose from and you start the game with 50000GP enough to buy a decent assault rifle permanent or rent all bunch of stuff. Compared to all that CS is much more limited, plain and simple, which as I said, has its good sides.  TI compared to Call of Duty is still “realistic”, so no any air strikes, missiles etc, maybe just the dogs are that little “too much”, but there is match limitation for them, so it is so so bearable.

Although TI is free to play, it is not (at least by my opinion) pay to win game, you can buy absolutely everything in the game with earned game points (GP) just by playing it, the only thing which cannot be bought with GP are the custom skins, which do not have any direct influence on your player specs.

If you want to have a look at the rest of that letter and the current issues with tha game here is the link:

There are so many good and so many bad things, which can be said about this game and this review, can be really long, but no one will read it, so it is waste of time for me to write it in details. All I will say is:

1.	I have bought CS:GO a week before I have installed TI and so far, I have accumulated 125 hours on TI, I am level 23 and I have bought quite few items (already have spend about 260,000GP) and I have accumulated just 6 hours on CS:GO and those are actually, because I have started to play CS:GO now/recently.

2.	I am a real world, skill/tactics based, FPS fan and TI had it all and more than any other FPS, I have ever played, but all the romance disappeared after I started to notice some serious unbalance in the game and after a while it is not anymore that much about skills, than just, what gadgets/items you have equipped. From that point on, it will start to become more and more a rat race to gain more GP and buy better armor, shoes, gloves etc, because it will highly influence your success rate, mind you I am not talking about the weapons…. and it begins to feel more like a RPG game than a skill game.  When you win or lose, you know and the rest of the players know (even, if some of them do not admit it), that most of the time you win or lose, because of the better gadgets/items you or they have equipped and the skill factor and the satisfaction of winning are pathetic, if you have to be honest to yourself.

3.	I do understand, that the game is F2P and the developers need to make money, but if I buy some DLC, I will become even more overpowered and it will be more like shooting fish in a barrel, than a fair challenge and satisfaction for all the players. I guess that is a common point for most F2P games and the main reason of their decease, which will be really pity for such a great game :(.

reviewText:
This game gets a lot of hate.  Sure the game isn't completely polished and it does suffer from a bug here or there, but really there aren't as many bugs as people make this game out to have.  I play BF4 as well and I find it has just as many bugs as this game, and the reviews for BF4 aren't as 1 sided as Tactical Intervention, when they really should be, not to mention BF4's god aweful client side / server side prediction hit test system.

Tactical Intervention is a server side hit detection game, with multiple game modes.  There are TDM style matches where you respawn after a few seconds, OR there are other game modes where you do NOT respawn, and have to wait for the rest of your team to either die too, or complete the objective in time... the ladder is by far the more fun of the two types as it promotes team play.

There objective modes like, plant the bomb, rescue the hostages and protect the VIP.
Protect the VIP is one of the most fun game modes in my opinion, especially the maps where you start in vehicles and have to stop or protect the VIP depending on which team you are playing on.  You and your team pile in a couple of cars and and have a shoot out while driving, the chaos is so much fun.

This game has the worst metacritic score out all the free to play games on steam which made it stand out for me, I downloaded it because I wanted to play it and see how bad it was and laugh, but there weren't any laughs to be had.. except those of enjoyment as this game is honestly a lot more fun than a lot of alternative shooters, free or otherwise.

Some people call it pay to win, but I disagree as you can buy mostly everything with GP (an in game currency rewarded each round for actions you perform, the better you do.. the more GP you get)   You can either rent or perminately buy weapons and equipment... oh and you can get an attack dog, which is pretty neat.  One thing you cannot buy with GP are new player skins, those you have to pay real money for, but other than a visual change they do nothing.  AND you can still get new helmets, gloves, boots and belts using GP anyway, which also give a visual and stat benefit to your character.

You start of with 50,000 GP and all but 2 or 3 guns can be permantly bought for that price.  (ranges from about 18,000 to 70,000ish GP on the weapons)  it does take some time to gain GP so you may be best renting a weapon for a day for the fraction of the cost first to see if you like it, before you perminately buy it.  Buy the time you are done fully testing the weapon you will probably have made back the GP you spent on renting it anyway.

You can also interact with a lot of objects like fire extingishers, gas canisters, you can rappel down a building..  and drive cars, trucks and an airport luggage taxi.


I can't stress enough though how much you should just try the game for yourself.  The game was to be the next counter strike and made by counter strike's co creator, but I think thats where the reviews went bad.  I believe counter strike players (there are a lot of them) expected this game to be better and possibly a replacement but it didn't turn out to be their cup of tea perhaps.  I recommend this game, it gets a lot more hate than it deserves.

You have 3 default weapons which are all good and balanced well and even the shotgun doesn't seem overpowered. The maps are fairly large with open space and little nooks and crannies. Most maps are designed for 6v6 gameplay although some maps are big enough to hold 24 players. There are the standard TDM but there is an interesting gamemode called Highway. As the name suggests you drive a car and shoot people in other cars and retrive the intel. Nothing in this game is unique but it is not supposed to. It is simply a F2P Counter Strike. However with all the problems the game has I would rather buy a $20 game like Counter Stike because it would provide a  better experience. Oh, did I mention the screen shake?\n\nBut to be fair, you get enjoyement when you play this game, which is why my final veredict for this game is a 7/10

reviewText: Hmmm, I have an urge to bash this game and say it is a blatent ripoff off of Counter Strike. But in all honesty, that doesn't do the game any justice. It has the same features as Counter Strike but how you play and what you do will greatly affect your experience. First of all, Graphically, it uses the Source engine so the graphics are decent but defineatly not great. On my machine at max settings, textures have the same resolution as a Minecraft block. Furthermore, the animations are stiff and unrealistic. However, just like in Counter Strike shooting is good. You have 3 default weapons which are all good and balanced well and even the shotgun doesn't seem overpowered. The maps are fairly large with open space and little nooks and crannies. Most maps are designed for 6v6 gameplay although some maps are big enough to hold 24 players. There are the standard TDM but there is an interesting gamemode called Highway. As the name suggests you drive a car and shoot people in other cars and retrive the intel. Nothing in this game is unique but it is not supposed to. It is simply a F2P Counter Strike. However with all the problems the game has I would rather buy a $20 game like Counter Stike because it would provide a  better experience. Oh, did I mention the screen shake?\n\nBut to be fair, you get enjoyement when you play this game, which is why my final veredict for this game is a 7/10

reviewText: Currently, I'm rank 16, and I've killed exactly 8712 other players, and have died 7622 times. I've won 196 matches, and have lost only 154 in comparison. The game in itself is strenuously challenging, but not impossible. I'm tempted to say that it's difficult to cope with at times, and is not for everyone. You need to be able to react fast, and build a common strategy as to how you'll get your next kill in. Spawn points are ridiculous, but it often favors random parties. Same goes to individuals, too. There's people who like to complain a lot by the way, about choice weapons, such as shotguns or the often spotted P90. It's mostly fun, though, to watch them ramble on and on about that last headshot you got in on them. All in all, noobs will be owned, but you can still easily work your way up with experience, and of course, the GP you earn with every match helps tremendously. Just be sure not to stray away from the shop. One can easily earn the necessary armor and weapons for more comfortable gameplay, or just flat out buy it with cold, hard cash, for not everything can be purchased with GP. At the same time, it doesn't take forever to save up GP either. As far as developing one's inventory goes, to each their own. One shouldn’t complain about another’s fix.

reviewText:
Tactical Intervention does look a lot like Counter Strike. Thsi is probably becausae it has been amde by I believe either the same company or developers that helped develop Counter Strike. I own counter strike and plodding through it I have to say I was not impressed. The one kill and you are dead during TDM (Team Death Match) was not fun as I constantly felt like a noob on it.

This game is better than Counter Strike. You can drive cars in VIP Escort (CT Mission) Assasinate VIP (Terrorists), you have the basic hostage rescue mission like CS and bomb mission again like CS.

You start with 3 choices of weapon, a Scorpion sub machine gun, a boklov shotgun and I believe an M1 rifle. All these weapons feel fairly light when going against enemys with xp paid/ premium paid weapons. Dont be fooled I have won matches where I was only team member against 2 other enemys with nothing but boklov shotgun. Give it a chance.

Maps dont look overly pretty but they feel so much fun to blow apart as if you play Office map on TDM or FFA you can blow CPU and filing trays apart to give better view or hide behind. The game feels like you have more startegy. In an escort mission as CT do you zoom ahead and meet the VIP at the drop off point where you are ready to defend or smash terrorist off the road and just generally slow them down, or stick with the VIP car no matter what. Tires can be shot out and if your car gets trashed GTA mother**&&^^ andjust chuck a civilian out GTA style. Dont run them over though that cost you 80 xp points. Kills usually get you 20 unless its  a head shot 1 kill where you get 40 xp.

The VIP looks liek an indavidual charchter he looks like a French Gendarme.

Maps are varied and you have about 15 ounds 7 as CT and 8 as Terrorists. When you shoot a man at point blank range in the chest with a shitgun...he knows about it as bits of red meat fly over the map. So much fun.

In short this feels an interesting look and very indavidual version of a fairly old format cops and robbers. If like me you see Battlefield Hardline but remember Origin wouldnt allow you to play your Battlefield 3 game because it asked for you to sownload plugin endlessly and nothing happened, just take my advice stick with tthis game. You can even buy a dog for 1000 xp if I remember correctly.May be a little more.

All in all hillarious, and for the first 9 level you can play with players of the same level if you are like me and want to play European servers but its a day when not many playing go to USA 1 server up to 250 people playing on a good day and I find connection is ok.

reviewText:
While this game wasn't a big hit, it has a certain charm to it that has kept me coming back. A friend recommended it to me and I was skeptical at first, but after playing a while I found I really enjoyed it. I also found out that a lot of what people say about it is wrong.

First, it is not pay to win, and the grinds for guns are hardly long at all, compared to other online games.

Secondly, I realize that it is fairly cheaply made, but for free? You can hardly beat that. The only things that cost money only are skins, which do nothing. I have not spent a cent on this game, and yet I am just about to purchase the most expensive weapon.

Thirdly, the gamemodes are fun, especially the vip escort missions, which usually end up looking wacky and hilarious. Their is a moderate team element to this game as well, so that is always nice to know.

Lastly, I was looking for a simple mmofps that wasn't pay to win and consistently fun, this was it.

The only downside to this game is that it is filled with children who spam the mic and complain, but you can always mute them, and airheads who think they are immortals among men. However, these problems typically pollute every online game. Overall, it is a fun, free experience, and I intend on playing it for a long time, try it before you judge!
